questions: Q. 1. Name the cells that regulates the opening and closing of stomata.
answers: Ans. Plywood industry.

questions: Q. 4. Which meristem leads to growth in length?
answers: Ans. The meristematic regions that arises from root apical meristems are: (i) Protoderm, (ii) Procambium, (iii) Ground meristerm.

questions: Q. 7. From where does the lateral root originate?
answers: Ans. Pericycle of mature zone.

questions: Q. 8. Name the tissues which provides mechanical strength to the plant organs.
answers: Ans. Sclerenchyma tissues.

questions: Q. 9. What is conjunctive tissue?
answers: Ans. It is a narrow strip of tissue (parenchyma or sclerenchyma) that lies between xylem and phloem bundles of root.

questions: Q. 10. What is the economic use of phloem fibres?
answers: Ans. They are used for making threads, ropes and coarse textiles.

questions: Q. 11. Name the tissue represented by the jute fibres that are used for making the ropes.
answers: Ans. Bast fibre (Phloem fibre).

questions: Q. 12. What are stomata?
answers: Ans. Minute pores present on the surface of leaves are called stomata. They are meant for exchange of gases.

questions: Q. 13. What are cotton fibres?
answers: Ans. Cotton fibres are unicellular epidermal hair of seed of Gossypium sps.

questions: Q. 14. What is a bark?
answers: Ans. Bark is the dead tissue, lying outside the cork cambium.

questions: Q. 15. Define promeristem.
answers: Ans. It is a part of apical meristem made up of actively dividing cells and their immediate derivatives.

questions: Q. 16. Why is the root apical meristem sub-terminal?
answers: Ans. Root apical meristem is sub-terminal because of the presence of a protective terminal root cap over it.

questions: Q. 17. Name two types of parenchyma present in leaf?
answers: Ans. Palisade and spongy parenchyma.

questions: Q. 18. Name the cells that surround vascular bundles in dicot leaf. [DDE Practice Paper]
answers: Ans. Vascular bundles are surrounded by a bundle sheath of parenchymatous cells.

questions: Q. 19. Define calyptrogen.
answers: Ans. It is a special meristematic region at the end of the root that given rise to cap.

questions: Q. 20. What is quiescent centre?
answers: Ans. It is a small region with low mitotic activity in the centre of the root apex.

questions: Q. 21. What are casparian strips?
answers: Ans. These are the thickenings of lignin and suberin formed around the anticlinal walls of endodermis to prevent plasmolysis.

questions: Q. 22. What is an annual ring?
answers: Ans. It is also called growth ring. A single growth ring formed each year is called annual ring.

questions: Q. 23. What is the function of cock in plants?
answers: Ans. Cork insulates the tree against heat and cold.

questions: Q. 24. When do you refer a vascular bundle as a closed bundle?
answers: Ans. When cambium is absent.

questions: Q. 25. What forms the cambial ring in a dicot stem during the secondary growth?
answers: Ans. Fascicular and interfascicular strips of meristems.

questions: Q. 26. What are collateral vascular bundles?
answers: Ans. Conjoint bundles with xylem towards the inner side and phloem towards the outer side.

questions: Q. 27. Name the plant I which bicollateral vascular bundles are found.
answers: Ans. Cucurbita maxima (Kaddu).

questions: Q. 28. What are the cells included in a stele?
answers: Ans. The cells included in a stele are Pericycle, vascular strands and pith.

questions: Q. 29. What is the function of pith cells?
answers: Ans. Pith cells store food in the form of starch.

questions: Q. 30. What is Lysogineous cavity?
answers: Ans. In a mature vascular bundle, some of the protoxylem vessels and the xylem parenchyma cells dissolve or separate to form a water containing cavity Lysogineous cavity.
